Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Tuning Electronic Phases in Layered Complex Oxides
Award.AbstractNarration:
This CAREER project is jointly funded by Electronic and Photonic Materials and Ceramic programs.

Technical: The main scope of this CAREER project aims to synthesize and characterize nanostructured complex perovskite oxide thin films exhibiting strong electron correlation. Controlling electronic phase transitions in these systems requires excellent materials quality with greatly reduced defect densities, nanoscale carrier confinement of ultrathin layers and atomically sharp interfaces. Research is focused on artificial layered structures to achieve low dimensional electron liquids in the limit of extreme carrier concentrations. Hybrid molecular beam epitaxy is employed to grow quantum well heterostructures, where the confinement is achieved using band discontinuities at nonpolar interfaces. The goal is to explore how materials design parameters available in thin film growth, namely strain, dimensional confinement, chemical doping and layering scheme, affect the stability of the electronic phases of these two-dimensional electron liquids. Advanced spectroscopic and structural characterization techniques are employed in combination with temperature-dependent thermoelectric and thermomagnetic as well as magneto-transport properties to correlate Fermi surface modifications with atomic scale design of these artificial electronic material systems.

Non-technical: The project addresses fundamental questions and basic research challenges in the emerging field of oxide electronics. Understanding phenomena arising from strong electron correlation provides a path to discover, tailor and utilize electronic materials with functionalities beyond conventional semiconductor materials. Research results are expected to significantly impact the development of energy-efficient and ultrafast logic devices for future computation schemes. The project activities contain a strong educational and outreach component embedded in the existing outreach programs at Penn State. Two interactive demonstration packages are created to illustrate scientific and technological concepts relevant to the research. A functional model analog of a molecular beam epitaxy system is built allowing young students to grow layered structures using spherical objects representing atoms. An intuitive and tangible interactive package of metronomes is developed to help exploring various aspects of correlation effects using the synchronization behavior of metronomes to conceptualize coupling based on mutual interactions. The flexible design of the demonstration packages allow versatile utilization for a variety of outreach activities, including museum exhibits, class room and workshop activities, and science festivals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project is to synthesize crystalline functional oxide materials utilizing a method called hybrid molecular beam epitaxy that allows to control the atomic layer sequence in the crystalline film, forming abrupt interfaces and thus created materials not attainable otherwise. The ability to control the type of layers stacked, specifically the elemental composition, and the layer sequence as well as the number and distance of interfaces formed in this artificially designed materials stack allows to create novel nanostructures that offers the ability to design the material and craft the desired properties at the atomic level. The targeted material systems were thin films, but also heterostructure, i.e. films with similar crystal structure but made from different elements,  and superlattices – a sequence of heterostructures – of perovskite oxides containing the elements titanium and vanadium. These material systems exhibit a sizeable electron-electron interaction, which give rise to peculiar phenomena that are beyond electronic properties of conventional semiconductor materials and are therefore potentially useful to augment semiconductor material properties to enhance the computational performance of servers, laptops and mobile phones while reducing power requirements to operate these devices. The basic requirement to achieve these intellectual merits is to demonstrate and establish a method to grow these titanate and vanadate thin films with unprecedented perfection, ideally rivaling the material quality that is nowadays routinely achieved for conventional semiconductor materials. To that end the following outcomes of the project have been produced.

Extensive growth efforts of SrVO3 thin films have shown that a self-regulated growth kinetics of hybrid MBE can be achieved at higher temperature. It marked the first experimental proof that the advantages of this thin film growth method can be expanded to vanadium perovskite structures. The favorable growth kinetics was further demonstrated for the two material systems CaTiO3 and CaVO3 as well along with a detailed analysis of defect types formed in films grown under non-stoichiometric conditions. The hybrid MBE method has been further expanded to quaternary oxide systems and was found to produce films of excellent quality. In addition, the growth of perovskite oxide films on Si has been demonstrated as well, potentially paving an economically viable way to integrate perovksites on the Si platform in a scalable way. A combinatorial approach to supply vanadium in different valence states has been developed that resulted in a marked improvement over oxidation states in thin films of VO2, a long-standing challenge given the multivalent nature of the transition metal element vanadium. This advancement of the film quality achieving a large resistivity change over four orders of magnitude across the metal-to-insulator transition of VO2 with superior homogeneity and excellent uniformity has been achieved on wafer scale, making it (1) an ideal candidate as material for electronic switches by uniquely balancing the trade-off between high operating frequencies and fast and reliable switching characteristics, (2) enabling Non-Boolean computing schemes via synchronization behavior of VO2 based oscillators, and (3) providing a strategy to augmenting Si-based technology and achieving superior switching characteristics establishing the fundamentals towards low power high performance logic. Fabricating three-terminal switches in a field effect transistor geometry from wafer-scale grown VO2 has allowed to demonstrate that the metal-to insulator transition is reversible, i.e. a gate modulation can also collapse the high conductance ON-state of the transistor. A further outcome of this project was the discovery of a new paradigm to create materials that are both electrically conducting and optically transparent in the visible range. While so far the only materials class were highly doped wide band gap semiconductors, in particular ITO, it was demonstrated that correlated metals grown and characterized in this project, specifically vanadate thin films SrVO3 and CaVO3, are uniquely suited displaying performance similar to the current state of the art material ITO. Based on this discovery a patent was granted. Educational component was tightly intertwined and throughout the project a total of seven research project opportunities were provided to undergraduate students. Four undergraduate senior thesis projects have resulted and in addition a team of three undergraduate students were advised on a learning factory project to build a model of a molecular beam epitaxy system as a demonstration set for outreach activities that allows a hands-on explanation of the principles of this thin film growth technique.
